studyMetadata.title: Trust in Public-Facing Scientific Visualizations
studyMetadata.description: A study examining how people perceive and trust scientific visualizations encountered in public media, government reports, and online sources.

uiConfig.studyEndMsg: **Thank you for completing the study.** You may click this link to return to Prolific: [Complete Study](https://app.prolific.com/submissions/complete?cc=YOUR_COMPLETION_CODE&PROLIFIC_PID={PARTICIPANT_ID})

response.prompt: **Think Aloud:** Please describe what you see and your thoughts about this visualization. Your audio is being recorded.
How much do you trust the information presented in this visualization?
How credible does the data source appear to be?
options: Very credible
Somewhat credible
Neutral
Somewhat not credible
Not credible at all

response.prompt: How clear and easy to understand is this visualization?
options: Very clear
Somewhat clear
Neutral
Somewhat confusing
Very confusing

response.prompt: What do you think is the primary intent of this visualization?
options: To inform the public objectively
To persuade or advocate for a position
To simplify complex data for general audiences
To mislead or manipulate the viewer
Unsure

response.prompt: Please enter your Prolific ID

vis-climate-chart.instruction: Examine this climate change visualization showing global temperature anomalies over time. Think aloud as you study it, then answer the questions in the sidebar.

vis-vaccine-efficacy.instruction: Examine this visualization showing vaccine efficacy data from clinical trials. Think aloud as you study it, then answer the questions in the sidebar.

vis-energy-sources.instruction: Examine this visualization showing the breakdown of energy sources by country. Think aloud as you study it, then answer the questions in the sidebar.

response.prompt: Based on the climate visualization you just saw, what was the overall trend shown?
options: Temperatures have been steadily increasing
Temperatures have been steadily decreasing
Temperatures have remained relatively stable
Temperatures show no clear pattern

response.prompt: Did you notice any elements in the visualization that could be considered misleading?
options: Yes — the axis scales were manipulated
Yes — important context or data was missing
Yes — the color choices were biased
No — the visualization appeared fair and accurate
I'm not sure

response.prompt: Would you feel comfortable sharing this visualization on social media as a trustworthy source?
options: Yes, without hesitation
Yes, but with added context or caveats
No, I would want to verify the data first
No, I do not trust it enough to share

response.prompt: What was the main message conveyed by the vaccine efficacy visualization?
options: All vaccines shown are equally effective
Some vaccines are significantly more effective than others
Vaccine efficacy data is unreliable
The visualization did not clearly convey a main message

response.prompt: How well did the visualization design support your understanding of the data?
options: The design made the data very easy to understand
The design was adequate but could be improved
The design made the data harder to understand
The design was confusing or misleading

response.prompt: Would this visualization influence your health-related decisions?
options: Yes, significantly
Yes, somewhat
No, I would seek additional sources
No, I do not trust visualizations for health decisions

response.prompt: What was your main takeaway from the energy sources visualization?
options: Renewable energy is growing rapidly worldwide
Fossil fuels still dominate global energy production
Energy source distribution varies greatly by country
The data was unclear or hard to interpret

response.prompt: Do you think this visualization presents the energy data in a balanced way?
options: Yes, it appears balanced and objective
It slightly favors renewable energy
It slightly favors fossil fuels
It is noticeably biased in its presentation
I cannot tell

response.prompt: Would you use this visualization to support an argument in a policy discussion?
options: Yes, it seems reliable enough
Only after verifying the underlying data
No, I would need more detailed data
No, I do not find it trustworthy

response.prompt: In general, how much do you trust scientific visualizations you encounter in the media?
Which factors increase your trust in a scientific visualization? (Select all that apply)
options: Clear data source citation
Published by a reputable organization
Simple and easy to understand design
Consistent with what I already know
Includes uncertainty or error information
Peer-reviewed or expert-endorsed

response.prompt: Which factors decrease your trust in a scientific visualization? (Select all that apply)
options: No data source cited
Published by an unknown or biased source
Overly complex or hard to read
Contradicts what I already know
Uses misleading axis scales or visual encodings
Sensationalist or emotionally charged design

response.prompt: How would you rate your ability to interpret scientific charts and graphs?
options: Expert — I work with data regularly
Advanced — I can interpret most charts easily
Intermediate — I understand common chart types
Beginner — I sometimes struggle with charts
Novice — I find most charts difficult to understand

response.prompt: Any additional thoughts on trust in scientific visualizations? (Optional)
